pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
Project Number: 46940 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
January 2013 
 
 
 
 
Trade Finance Capacity Development, Phase 2
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
DMC  –  developing member country  
TA  –  technical assistance 
TFP  –  Trade Finance Program 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance 
(R-CDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Industry and trade (trade and services) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency 
and enabling business environment), regional 
cooperation and integration (trade and investments), 
capacity development (institutional development) 
Location impact  –  Rural (medium), urban (medium), national (medium), 
regional (high) 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  P. Erquiaga, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Officer in Charge  S. Hruschka, Private Sector Financial Institutions Division, PSOD 
   
Team leader  S. Beck, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Team members  B. Huang, Investment Specialist, PSOD 
E. Mangampat, Investment Officer, PSOD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The proposed regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) is a second 
phase continuation of a successful TA that complements the development impact of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Trade Finance Program (TFP). Moreover, this TA is critical to the 
functioning of the TFP as it provides additional resources required to conduct financial analysis, 
due diligence, and annual reviews of the TFP obligor (and potential obligor) banks in developing 
member countries (DMCs), banks on which the TFP assumes risk.1 
 
2.  The TA is linked to a number of ADB strategies and business opportunities as presented 
in  (i)  country  partnership  strategies,  (ii)  regional  cooperation  strategies,  and  (iii)  country 
operations business plans for ADB's DMCs. A review of these documents underscores the 
importance of trade finance capacity development in the DMCs to enable ADB to meet its 
development objectives. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The TA focuses on trade development issues that impede trade, including financing. 
Many DMC banks struggle to establish and/or maintain correspondent banking relationships 
with international banks—relationships that are needed to access loans and guarantees in 
support of trade. Some factors (e.g., political and macroeconomic instability) are beyond their 
control, but DMC banks often lack knowledge of trade finance instruments, and may be unable 
to provide standard financial information to international banks. Such information is required to 
establish trade finance lines of credit between international and DMC banks. The lack of trade 
finance and financial reporting capacity among many DMC banks extends to transparency and 
governance issues, and reduces credit line availability from international banks. As a result, less 
financial support is available for DMC companies engaged in importing and exporting goods and 
services. This reduces the availability and increases the cost of trade finance in many less-
developed countries, hindering their full participation in international trade, lowering economic 
growth and job creation potential. 
 
4.  The  TA  will  build  on  ongoing  work  under  ADB’s  TA  for  Trade  Finance  Capacity 
Development, (in other words Phase 1), which started in 2009 and was extended from 1 July 
2012 to 31 January 2013.2 Phase 1 of the TA provided in-depth credit analysis on over 100 
DMC  banks  which  enabled  ADB  to  establish  credit  limits  on  banks  that  underpinned  the 
exponential growth of the TFP and its related development impact and mobilization of most of 
ADB’s commercial co-financing.  In addition, Phase 1 provided training to banks to improve their 
capacity to provide trade finance to companies, including many SMEs. The proposed Phase 2 
TA is required because the TFP will continue indefinitely – the Board agreed in July 2012 to 
delete the TFP’s 2013 sunset clause.  The TA provides TFP with much needed resources, 
including to: (i) conduct annual reviews of TFP participating obligor banks; (ii) conduct reviews 
of new potential TFP participating banks, including in new markets such as Myanmar; (iii) 
provide capacity building for DMC banks.        
 
 
   
                                                
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 March 2009. 
2  ADB. 2009. Technical Assistance for Trade Finance Capacity Development. Manila (TA 7264-REG).

2   
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
5.  The impact of the TA will be sustained economic growth and improved living standards 
through the expansion of international and intraregional trade. Trade is a highly effective tool to 
help developing countries boost economic growth and generate the resources necessary to 
reduce poverty. Moreover, maintaining and enhancing trade finance lines in a countercyclical 
environment can enable the DMCs to acquire critical goods—including medicine, food, fuel, and 
inputs for export production—needed for subsistence and/or fundamental economic activity. The 
outcome  of the TA  will  be  enhanced  capacity  in  the  DMCs  and  DMC  banks,  resulting  in 
increased trade finance to support trade in the DMCs. Specific outcome targets and the design 
and monitoring framework are in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
6.  The TA outputs and key activities are linked to the operation and on-going expansion of 
the TFP. Currently, the TFP involves 119 international banks and 82 DMC banks, 48 of which 
were added since January 2010. The 82 DMC banks are located in Afghanistan, Armenia, 
Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, Cambodia, Georgia, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, 
Mongolia,  Nepal,  Pakistan,  Philippines,  Sri  Lanka,  Tajikistan,  Uzbekistan,  and  Viet  Nam. 
Ongoing monitoring and trade finance capacity building for these banks would be among the 
key TA activities. The number of DMC banks will increase to about 95 by the end of 2013. 
Accordingly,  this  TA  will  also  benefit  new  banks  in  the  TFP’s  target  countries  including 
Myanmar, Turkmenistan, Timor Leste, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, and Samoa.3 The TA will have 
the following outputs for the 12 months from February 2013 to January 2014.  
 
1.  Knowledge Building in Developing Member Countries  
 
a.  DMC Bank Assessments and Capacity Building  
 
7.  From February 2013 to January 2014, consultants engaged to deliver the TA will work in 
the  field  and  conduct  about  32  assessments  of  new  banks,  approximately  99  monitoring 
assessments of banks already participating in TFP, and 24 assessments of country risk and 
banking system. Through this work, ADB will undertake due diligence of the targeted individual 
DMC banks4 to identify and characterize gaps in their financial and technical capacity that would 
inhibit the provision and/or increase of trade finance credit lines. Information derived from the 
TA will benefit DMC banks by specifically identifying where they lack capacity, and will enable 
ADB to provide capacity development that is tailored and specific to individual DMC banks and 
specific DMC banking systems. 
 
8.  The  periodic  bank-monitoring  assessments  are  based  on  the  principle  of  repeat 
engagement, which views capacity building in the medium and long term (i.e., something that 
cannot be achieved through a single engagement). The TFP will undertake annual financial 
assessments (and/or quarterly covenant reviews). The annual reviews will help solidify capacity 
development, and create benchmarks enabling assessment of year-to-year improvements or 
declines in the capacity of a DMC to support trade finance credit lines. ADB expects 131 bank 
assessments will be conducted under the TA from February 2013 to January 2014. 
                                                
3  The priority of countries targeted may change according to demand. Also, TFP expansion plans will be dependent 
on additional human resources. 
4  The TA will target banks that have market demand for capacity development and will coordinate with the TFP in 
this regard.

3 
 
9.  In addition to financial due diligence, the TA may fund technical assessments and due 
diligence of the trade finance operations of DMC banks. The assessments will review existing 
capabilities and identify gaps and weaknesses. The due diligence would be intended to audit 
documentation associated with trade loan transactions. This trade finance due diligence may 
involve visits to beneficiary companies. Based on the results of the technical assessments, the 
consultants will work with TFP to recommend improvements in current systems, operations 
procedures, and risk management that the consultant is expected to deliver through customized 
in-house training programs from February 2013 to January 2014.5  
 
10.  The TA activities include:  
(i)  work with individual DMC banks to acquire financial data; 
(ii)  analyze the financial information through financial, ratio, gap, and other analyses; 
(iii)  conduct due diligence with TFP staff for DMC banks by (a) meeting with banks; 
(b)  assessing  corporate  governance,  anti-money  laundering  policies,  and 
management capabilities; and (c) asking questions related to financial analysis; 
(iv)  assess the trade finance operations capacity of selected banks and support the 
TFP in making recommendations for improvement; 
(v)  draft credit applications to be submitted to the TFP; 
(vi)  conduct a banking system analysis for each DMC; and 
(vii)  deliver training related to trade finance. 
 
b.  Knowledge Dissemination and Training Seminars 
 
11.  Information derived from the TA’s financial assessments on individual banks will be 
conveyed directly to those banks on a confidential basis. In addition, the TA proposes to 
disseminate  more  general  information  about  DMCs’  banking  sectors  and  trade  finance 
operations to a larger audience within the DMCs through in-country seminars to which DMC 
banks, exporters, government officials (including central bank officials), and international banks 
may be invited, as appropriate. 
 
12.  The seminars will contribute to the development of the banking sector and trade finance 
in DMCs where both are still at a nascent stage of development. 
 
13.  The contents of each seminar will be fine-tuned to meet the requirement of the target 
audience.  
 
14.  ADB plans to conduct four seminars over the course of the TA: one in Myanmar, one in 
Kyrgyz Republic, one in Turkmenistan, and one in Papua New Guinea.6 
 
2.  Partnership Development 
 
15.  TA  consultants  will  work  in  the  field,  in  coordination  with  the  TFP,  to  develop 
partnerships  between  international  and  DMC  banks.  Developing  partnerships—such  as 
correspondent banking relationships with international banks—is critical to fostering the financial 
support (trade finance credit lines) that underpins international and regional trade in the DMCs. 
 
16.  By  assessing  the  financial  position  of  various  DMC  banks  and  through  TFP’s 
relationships and mechanism for disseminating knowledge, the TA will help to bridge the gap 
                                                
5  The number of in-house training programs will depend on the results of technical assessment and needs of the 
DMC banks. 
6  The countries may change based on changing demand.

4   
between  DMC  and  international  banks,  and  indirectly  between  exporting  and  importing 
companies. Furthermore, the TFP has listed on its website all DMC banks that have received 
approval of ADB’s trade finance credit limits, enabling international banks to identify potential 
banking partners in ‘frontier markets’. Working in conjunction with the TFP, the TA will explicitly 
and implicitly create the opportunity for international banks to consider those DMC banks to be 
correspondent banks. These relationships will support increased flows of capital and goods 
essential for economic activity and job creation. 
 
17.  The TFP expansion plans cover a multiyear period. The table provides a summary of the 
TA (phase 2) outputs for February 2013–January 2014, together with the actual output during 
2009–2011 and expected output until January 2013 under the first (phase 1) TA for Trade 
Finance Capacity Development. 
 
 Outputs for Technical Assistance Over Five Years 
Trade Finance Capacity Development 
 
 
TA, Phase 1
 
  Actual  Projected  Proposed TA 
  2012-  Feb 2013- 
2009 - 2011

New bank assessments  76  10  327 
Bank-monitoring assessments  157  101  99 
Country risk and banking system assessments  33  21  24 
Seminars  5  4 
 
TA = technical assistance. 
a  Asian Development Bank. 2009. Technical Assistance for Trade Finance Capacity Development. Manila. 
Source: Trade Finance Program, Private Sector Financial Institutions Division, Asian Development Bank. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department will administer and implement the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The TA will require approximately 120 person-months of consulting inputs. The 
outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 2. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
19.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $3,000,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  Trade  Finance  Capacity 
Development, Phase 2. 
                                                
7 The number of new bank assessments will depend on TFP acquiring more staff to accommodate and manage TFP 
expansion to the Pacific region.

Appendix 2  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Under  the  regional  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA),  a  reputable 
consultancy firm will be hired to undertake capacity building and provide the outputs referred to 
in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). Individual consultants may be engaged 
for some TA components, as and when required. 
 
A.  Objective and/or Purpose of the Assignment 
2.  The TA will increase the capacity of developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to attract and retain trade finance credit lines to important exporting 
DMC companies. This is achieved primarily through financial analysis and due diligence of DMC 
banks. The TA will enhance the trade finance capacity of DMC banks by providing in-house 
training and knowledge dissemination seminars. 
 
3.  This assignment is designed to (i) identify capacity gaps that impede DMC banks from 
maintaining  and  accessing  trade  finance  credit  lines;  (ii)  based  on  the  results  of  financial 
analysis and due diligence for potential partner banks in the Trade Finance Program (TFP) and 
annual reviews of existing TFP partner banks, recommend if specific DMC banks are suitable 
for (ongoing) participation in the TFP; (iii) identify measures to enhance capacity to access, 
maintain, and enhance trade finance credit lines from international banks; (iv) through the lead 
consultant, coordinate field work with the TFP and ADB’s Office of Risk Management to ensure 
the TA efforts complement TFP expansion; and (v) provide technical training to banks and 
conduct knowledge-sharing seminars to wider audiences. 
 
B.  Required Inputs:  
1.  Team Leader (international bank financial analysis expert, 12 person-months) 
4.  Scope of work. The team leader will oversee necessary capacity building in the DMCs 
to expand ADB's TFP. The consultant will (i) act as ADB's primary point of contact with the eight 
bank financial analysis experts and one trade finance expert; (ii) provide quality control and 
coherence to the work being conducted by the bank financial analysis experts; (iii) perform 
additional functions similar to the financial analysis experts; and (iv) coordinate with the trade 
finance expert regarding the technical assessment of trade finance operations, capacity building, 
and seminars on trade finance. 
 
5.  The tasks of the consultant include  
 
(i)  act as ADB's main point of contact for bank financial analysis experts, maintain 
regular contact with ADB, and coordinate and disseminate information in both 
directions; 
(ii)  set work schedules and ensure deadlines are met; 
(iii)  review draft and final draft credit applications produced by the bank financial 
analysis experts; 
(iv)  provide quality control and ensure coherence of the work of the other consultants; 
(v)  coordinate  with  ADB  and  appropriate  government  and  finance  sector  DMC 
entities to arrange dates and other logistics for seminars to disseminate findings 
from the DMC bank and DMC banking system analyses; and 
(vi)  organize seminars with the trade finance expert and ADB staff.

8  Appendix 2 
 
2.  Bank  Financial  Analysis  Experts  (8  international  consultants;  total  of  96 
person-months) 
 
6.  Scope  of  work.  The  consultants  will  work  in  the  field  with  DMC  banks  located 
throughout Asia and the Pacific; the work will require extensive travel. They will coordinate with 
various  ADB  regional  departments  and  the  TFP  (within  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department) and the Office of Risk Management. 
 
7.  To identify capacity gaps hindering the ability to maintain and attract more trade finance, 
and to garner the maximum development effect from an expansion of the TFP, capacity building 
will focus on (i) financial analysis, (ii) due diligence, and (iii) writing of credit applications and 
reports. 
 
8.  The tasks of the consultants include  
 
(i)  acquire financial information on targeted DMC banks; 
(ii)  provide information into ADB's risk-rating model; 
(iii)  conduct financial, ratio, gap, and other analyses of financial information; 
(iv)  conduct  due  diligence  on  the  DMC  banks  by  (a)  meeting  with  the  banks;  
(b)  assessing  corporate  governance,  anti-money  laundering  policies,  and 
management capabilities; and (c) asking questions that arise from the financial 
analyses; 
(v)  based on the information accumulated from (i) to (iii), draft credit applications for 
the TFP; 
(vi)  draft and submit a banking system analysis for each DMC; and 
(vii)  provide feedback and inputs, as necessary, to the lead consultant with respect to 
organizing seminars. 
 
3.  Trade Finance Expert (international; total of 12 person-months) 
 
9.  Scope of work. The trade finance expert, who may be engaged independent of any 
contract with Business & Finance Consulting, will be responsible for (i) conducting technical 
assessments  of  trade  finance  operations  for  DMC  banks  with  new  or  small  trade  finance 
operations; (ii) proposing measures for improving trade finance operations; (iii) providing in-
house training to bank staff involved in trade finance; (iv) conducting knowledge dissemination 
and/or training seminars aimed at a wider audience; and (v) conducting due diligence on DMC 
bank trade finance operations as required.  
 
10.  The tasks of the consultant include  
 
(i)  conduct technical assessments of trade finance operations for DMC banks to 
identify gaps, weaknesses, and key risk areas for selected banks; 
(ii)  propose concrete measures to fill the gap and mitigate risks identified by the 
technical assessment, including recommendations for improvements in systems, 
operations procedures, and risk management; 
(iii)  provide customized in-house training to selected DMC bank staff involved in 
trade finance operations; 
(iv)  conduct  trade  finance  due  diligence,  including  documentation  checks  and/or 
audits, and possibly visits to beneficiary companies; 
(v)  conduct knowledge dissemination and/or training seminars aiming at a wider 
audience; this could cover the following topics: (a) key concepts and processes

Appendix 2  9 
in trade finance, (b) benefits to banks from trade finance services, (c) essentials 
to develop and market trade finance products and services, (d) payment and risk 
categories,  (e)  risk  analysis  of  trade  finance  products,  (f)  fundamentals  of 
documentary credits, (g) types of letters of credit and standby credit, (h) types of 
bonds and guarantees, and (i) receivables and supply chain financing. 
 
C.  Outputs and/or Reporting Requirements 
11.  Outputs and reporting requirements for the consulting firm include the following: 
 
(i)  provide regular reports and updates on work progress by the bank financial 
analysis experts; 
(ii)  submit good quality, cohesive annual reviews (99 from February 2013 to January 
2014), new credit applications (32 from February 2013 to January 2014), and 
banking system analyses (24 from February 2013 to January 2014); 
(iii)  conduct knowledge-sharing seminars with importers and exporters, DMC bank 
staff, and government officials: two in 2013; and, 
(iv)  conduct in-house training in two DMC banks (from February 2013 to January 
2014).

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Regional—Capacity development technical assistance 
(R-CDTA) 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Industry and trade (trade and services) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency 
and enabling business environment), regional 
cooperation and integration (trade and investments), 
capacity development (institutional development)

regional (high)
